move on.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to leave your present job, class, or activity and start doing another one
move on.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: I enjoyed my job, but it was time to move on.
Jeremy’s leaving the company to move on to higher things.
When you finish, move on to the next exercise.
move on.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to develop in your life, and change your relationships, interests, activities etc
move on.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: I’ve moved on since high school, and now I don’t have much in common with some of my old friends.
She has long since moved on from the roles of her youth.
move on.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to change, progress, improve, or become more modern as time passes
move on.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: By the time the software was ready, the market had moved on.
move on.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to order someone to leave a particular place – used especially about police
move on.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The police arrived on the scene and began moving the protesters on.
move on.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to start talking about a new subject in a discussion, book etc
move on.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: Before we move on, does anyone have any questions?
move on.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to leave the place where you have been staying and continue to another place
move on.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: After three days we decided it was time to move on.
The exhibition has now moved on to Edinburgh.
move on.translation[0].definitions[6].de: if time, the year etc moves on, the time passes
move on.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: As time moves on, I’d like the children to play more challenging music.
move on.translation[0].definitions[7].de: used to say that you must leave soon or do something soon, because it is getting late
move on.translation[0].definitions[7].ex: Time’s moving on – we’d better get back to the car.
